author: jmacqueen22

description.text:
Constructed in space and launched from the ISS, a group of transport modules will head to MARS. Containing the required supplies to get started along with raw minerals and the most advanced 3D and 4D range of printers, This group or brave individuals will be required to create most of their future requirements from these machines.
Once they arrive at MARS the transports unit equipped with the LDSD will enter the atmosphere of MARS and guide the transports in to their base configuration location. Each transport has the ability to support its current crew but has the ability to be retrofitted once the Main Base construction is completed and the transport units are linked to each other.
Making use of the 3D and 4D printers the colony would then begin to construct Solar Wind break sails around the existing transport modules to create a "Build Zone". Once done Construction on the main base can begin. Designed to be print friendly and of a modular construction method, the modules required that make up the catwalk, Base and Tower can printed and assembled.
Now the transports can be converted into different environments as required by the mission co-ordinator. Living Spaces, Waste and Medical facilities a must, however we are not restricted to what is possible in a transport module. Simulated Greenhouse, Experiment facilities and at worst case a liveable isolation chamber for an unexpected medical emergency are feasible fit outs.
Additional unmanned transport modules could also come along with some of the larger equipment required immediately upon arrival.
The Main Base allows for a large area air lock secured from the harsh environment to preassemble components and maybe store surface vehicles. Suited to sit in the recess in the Gale crater this gives us a good location (which we know about from the Curiosity rover) so we can locate the additional recourse required to be mined to be able to help sustain ongoing martin life on this planet.
3D printing the STL files at a 1:10 scale should work fine Thanks for this challenge! It was a good one!
wy

title: [1.5.1] 3uP - Metal H-Bot Upgrade for QUBD Two-Up

description.text:
Check out my newest printer, the Eclips3D! Loosely based on the widely popular 3uP
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1242295 Ready for printing! Instructions for assembly can be found here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UWPYx5udK98 Here is the 3d printed parts repository for my 3uP 3d printer. This printer is designed to reuse as many parts as possible from the QUBD Two-up in order to keep costs as low as possible. With that being said, you can still build this from scratch, you will just have to source some extra parts. At the moment, only the pieces for the XY gantry (as well as some other various parts) are up. The z-axis is still in the testing stages and should be released in about a week. At that point, the BOM will also be finalized. If you would like to print upgrades for the printer [they do not affect the print quality, simply cosmetics and ease of use], then head over here!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:386007 Also check out some upgrades by Brian Popilek and others for the 3uP, including the cable chain!
http://www.thingiverse.com/DDeGonge888/collections/3up-community-upgrades Link to the BOM
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ozUbu-w6AewCLxUbyd9cOa8SzkXXf9h4VX00BzZd4lA/edit?usp=sharing Forum page with all info (down as of July 2016)
http://www.fabric8r.com/forums/showthread.php?1742-3uP-Metal-Upgrade-Kit-Download-links-BOM-Instructions-and-Info&p=17063#post17063 Donate if you like!
http://goo.gl/5UThpG

All parts are oriented for printing. Some parts require cleanup, but it should be easy to find these parts. Holes for nuts may have to be widened ever so slightly to fit the hex nuts in.  
For quantities, see the BOM, which can be found by visiting the forum page mentioned on the previous page.

comments.text: Hello! I built your printer on ramps, and can not find the firmware under ramps. Maybe you know where you can download Marlin for a 3UP printer ??
comments.author: HardcoreCat

comments.text: The firmware is marlin but it is meant for the printrboard. You should be able to use the same firmware on a ramps board as long as you change in the firmware the motherboard selection to reflect the ramps. Some of the pinouts may change as well. It would be best to grab a fresh copy of ramps marlin and then just copy parameters over from the firmware I provide.
comments.author: HardcoreCat

comments.text: Can I expand the printable area with longer extrusions, rods and belt?
comments.author: s195t

comments.text: No.  I built that and the longer rods are way to compliant.  If you want a larger printer build something else.  I'm working on a larger printer that uses Hiwin rails.
comments.author: s195t

comments.text: Thank you for the quick reply :) Just one more question, the print quality on your 3up with longer rods it's so bad?
comments.author: napierm

comments.text: Didn't get there.  It is so bad I could easily move the Z-axis around, the Y movement back and forth, and the X-gantry back and forth, up/down and the twisting by more than 20 degrees in the center.  I'm not kidding.
comments.author: s195t

comments.text: Yeah the 3uP was never meant to be expanded, the current size of it was hitting the limits of the parts. For large printers, the best way to go is with linear rails or with v-slot extrusions and wheels. Linear ball bearings and bushings don't work so great when you get too large, and the hbot kinematics definitely were not meant to get that big. Corexy or bust.
comments.author: napierm

comments.text: I've almost completed all parts for the 3UP. Even though I printed with PolyMakr PolyMax, which is supposed to be tougher than PLA I'm not yet happy with the strength of some parts. I'd like to reprint a few parts in ColorFABB XT which is a great and strong material.
comments.author: JvdP

comments.text: The parts you want to be the strongest are y slider a1/a2/b1/b2/d1/d2 and x slider a/b. Depending on how they came out, you may not have to reprint all of those, they are just the ones that rely most on their strength for the printer to work well. Mainly, you want the torsional strength of y slider a1/a2 to be really good along the z axis (when in orientation for printing), and you want the others to just be pretty rigid in general.
comments.author: JvdP

description.text:
This is a replacement 3 button key fob case for Ford vehicles.  
I've included a 4 button key fob front. The additional Button open was made based on a photo. I don't have a 4 button remote to confirm the fit.

The model is designed with the necessary support built in. If you edit the Sketchup model the supports are individual objects and bright red.
(I've uploaded newer STL files with modified support and also STL files with the support removed to allow your software to add support)
This was printed with:
  • .3mm layer height. (also printed in .1mm)
  • 100% infill
  • No supports
  • ABS Plastic.
    • The tolerances and space for these remotes are pretty tight in order to get everything to line up and snap together.

comments.text: Sounds great, if you can find any photos of the furniture, especially Nemo's piano, could you please send me some so I can make them and put them on Thingiverse too. Also, make sure you run those panels through Project Miller before printing the parts. What I have discovered is that hollow parts on SketchUp have no thickness and therefore cant be printed unless they are solid objects. Project Miller will re-mesh the parts and make them 3D printable.
comments.author: Geoffro

comments.text: I actually use Blender for everything, and am pretty well versed at it now so I tend to manually do the work in that, it seems to be just as fast. It has a nice Solidify function you can apply and it also has an easy recalculation of normal maps, so the topology of the mesh ends up being quite watertight, with a nice hollow inside ready for infill or not, I will check out project miller, tho, cheers.

author: pandasta

description.text:
So recently I have been on a quest for a sealer that will make ABS look amazing after you file or sand the ever living crap out of it. I like to sand harsh 90 degree corners on personal handheld products like the phone cases and Arduino labs. The problem is it leaves sanding marks. Also ABS glue leaves behind a shinny look in areas that does not look pleasant. I bring you more of a public service information than a Thing-A-Ma-jig. Other clear coats just do not even cut it or feel sticky after awhile. These do not! Both products work about the same except I like Valspar frosting much better. It dries so fast! and covers the most aggressive tooling. Valspar works on PLA also. Rustoleum FAILS on PLA. See attached photos of test.
I hope you enjoy the tip ;)

Tool your product.
Spread ABS glue anywhere on it.
Wait till everything drys and spray the Renewing spray of your choice.

He goes through a process starting at 400 grit and finishes with 12000 grit sanding paper on soft back (foam core). There are NO MARKS after he's done. Another method is to use Brasso or Simichrome paste. For small parts I would use Simichrome. I use Brasso to finish my wood rifle stocks and people think I have coated them with glass.

comments.text: It goes without saying that tooling and sanding are pretty common sense things.Â  The thing I like about this is it really makes the ABS color pop from having a super even matte finish which will refract light. Most dulling sprays or matte sprays do this but not all are plastic friendly.Â  So the power of one that works so well is a very trial and error business especially for ABS.Â  Looks like pla is also a pain from what I saw in the rustoleum test. (I don't use PLA to often)

comments.author: MichaelAtOz

comments.text: Have you ever thought of using different grits of sandpaper? Coarser sandpaper will remove material quicker, but leave scratches, use 800 grit to sand first, then go to progressively finer grit paper until it's smooth, I recommend 2000-3000 grit auto body sandpaper for the final sanding, available at auto parts stores, or by the auto body stuff (bondo, spraypaint) at walmart. A final buffing with mirror glaze (meguiars show glaze, by the car wax) will finish it up just fine. Just like doing auto body work. If you have scratches, you're using too coarse a grit; The stuff used for woodworking is too much for plastic.

description.text:
This is a magnetic coupling concept that uses 10 of the Makerbot 3mm x 3mm x 3mm Neodymium magnets. These comes in handy when you need to couple two shafts together, but don't want to painstakingly axially align the shafts, within thousandths of an inch. I measured the holding torque of the coupling, with the magnets inserted into the couplings in both attraction and repulsion. I used a digital torque meter and analog torque watch, until the coupling slipped and recorded the data below. Attraction: ~43 in-oz
Repulsion: ~25 in-oz Accepts a 12mm shaft diameter. I plan to make couplings that have smaller shaft diameters later and I am also working on magnetic gears. Update: Added 3/16" (4.8mm)ID coupling; accepts shaft size of a NEMA 17.
Added a 1/4" (6.35mm) ID coupling; accepts a NEMA 23 sized shaft.

-Print out couplings and trim ( prints two at a time )
-Insert magnets in attraction or repulsion to the other coupling. Magnets will press fit in, but you can use glue or put tape over them to hold them in place.
-Put couplings on shaft, and use an M3 set screw or screw to hold them on.
-Roughly align the couplings and move them in close to each other.
-Now you have two shafts magnetically coupled, without the headache of axially aligning them! :)

description.text:
What's better than a 3D printed Low poly Gengar?  
A bouncy silicon low poly Gengar cast in a 3D printed mold!  
I cleaned up the polys in csl0304's awesome original model and applied Jason Webb's awesome 2 part mold generator after removing the code to add pour holes.There's not a whole lot of original work here just a mash-up of two great projects by other people.  Thanks guys you both rock.  
Pictures are of Gengar made out of Oogoo with green paint cuz I'm out of purple.

title: Model Rocket Fin Alignment Guide & Clips for BT-20 & BT-50 Body Tubes

description.text: Estes's Fin Alignment tool is really cool, but costs like $20, which is a bit steep if you have a club or school class trying to build a dozen rockets at the same time. I plan to add some photos of it in use in a bit... So I printed some Fin Alignment guides for 3, 4 & 5 fin rockets using BT-20 and BT-50 tubes. They take a little while to print, but way cheaper than buying a bunch of "real" tools. Don't forget to check out L3-G0, my completely unrelated working full size Lego R2-D2 on his blog at http://L3-G0.blogspot.com or YouTube.

Print one guide first to make sure it fits your tube. You may need to adjust the fudge factor in the stl. The files also have I.D. & O.D. for other tube sizes, so you can muck with the files to print more. Of course you'll also need to move the fins out a bit.... I'm expecting 1/8" ~ 3mm fin stock. If you have a different width fin stock you may need to either shim the fins when you attach them, or, if you do this a lot, adjust the STL to have a smaller offset. My first attempt was a stepped holder, but that doesn't help if the fins extend way below the tube, so don't print that one unless you really need it. Instead print the fin guide with the tall post BT-20 tube holder. If you need a BT-50, also print the "shim" to get it up to BT-50 size. What you need to print:
1) Appropriate # of fin guide(s). Make sure to use the ones with the tall center spoke unless you really want fins flush or above the bottom of the body tube.
-- Check the first one at least to make sure it fits a BT-20.
2) If you need a BT-50, then print the "shim" piece. It's supposed to slip over the previous guide to make it bigger for the bigger body tube.
-- If you're printing several, check the first couple to make sure it fits over the post in 1, and that the tube fits it well. I had to sand out the inside of my first one, which was a real pain.
3) Print clips. These clips are intended for about 1/8" balsa. You may need to make them skinnier, or add an extra bit of material to get enough grip. Using the fin guides:
1) Mark where you're putting the fins using your favorite method.
2) If you're using a BT-50, put the shim thing over the center post of the appropriate fin guide to make it big enough for your tube.
3) Check how the fins fit the body tube in the correct spot. Each of the guide vanes is off-center, expecting a 1/8" fin stock. Place the fins counter-clockwise to the vanes (away from the "Other Side" label). If you have the thin cardboard or balsa, you can either ignore the slight error or add a shim between the fin and the guide vane.
4) Use a clip to hold the fin in place. If you have thin stock you may need to adjust the clips or pad the gap with something. If you want to tweak the STL, there're some variables: In the Alignment Guide files:
FINOFFSET is how far the vane is from the centerline of the fin, so it should be 1/2 the thickness of your fin stock.
FINWIDTH and PLATE are the thickness of the parts, if they're too flimsy you could make them fatter.
FUDGE modifies the "optimal" values to account for print variation, etc. You can increase this if your tubes are too tight. In the clips files the options are commented, but it wasn't really intended for tons of variation, so you may need to tweak everything else. The most interesting things are:
LENGTH - how long the clips are, and
INNERWIDTH - How big the gap is. Fin Alignment Shim is "just" the tube that fits over the BT-20 post. You may need to adjust the "FUDGE" or radius if it doesn't fit nicely on your post or if the BT-50 is too tight on it. You can also change the 50/20 to other tube sizes if you changed the fin guides for other tube sizes. Don't forget to check out L3-G0, my completely unrelated working full size Lego R2-D2 on his blog at http://L3-G0.blogspot.com or YouTube.

At work, I used Moleskine notebook (Pro model ... or not) with hard-cover. When I went to meetings, I ofter lost my pen in the corridor... result: nothing to take notes, except paper. I designed the MOLESPENNY object to avoid that. Just slide the Molepenny once on a Moleskine hard-cover corner and you can now clip your pen ! For customization purpose, you can also have your NAME on it (or Company name for promotional object) NOTE:
This was designed for a Moleskine hard-cover and a BIC pen. To be adpated if the cover thickness is different or if the pen diameter is not the same. NOTE 2:
To design the text, antoher "Library" is used :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193 NOTE 3:
Additional information can be found on http://wiki.zgur.net/index.php/Molespenny NOTE 4:
This design is an Open Source design. However, if you use it, I would appreciate a small message ! :) Thank you !

• Download OPENSCAD tool : http://www.openscad.org/

  • Open the Molespenny.scad with OPENSCAD

  • Look for the line :
    write("Nekloth",h=5,t=2,font="orbitron.dxf",space=1.2);

  • Replace Nekloth by your name or company name.

  • Press F6 key to generate the STL file

  • Click on menu Design > Export as STL...

  • Object can be 3Dprinted ! ;-)

Here are a set of 100+ cookie cutter shapes. 
Cookie cutters are easy-to-print objects and pretty useful.

1) Select (a set of) your favorite cookie cutter. 2) Get it printed.
Print only the outline of the cutter so switch off all fill setting in your slicer. A rather rough layer height setting will do. 2 layer shells will produce a fine cutter. I sliced mine in Netfabb for Ultimaker where I added 3 extra shell layers to the bottom 3mm's of the cookie cutter (using the Regions option in Netfabb) giving it a bit more strength. 3) Make some cookie dough. I like sand cookies! You can check this site for a recipe and how-to
http://www.wikihow.com/Make-Sand-Cookies 4) Enjoy your cookies! The "All cookie cutters".zip obviously contains all the cookie cutters. I also added some ZIPs of related cookie cutters.

title: JPT's Low Profile Y-Carriage for Igus KSTM-08 Bearings on MendelMax 1.5

description.text:
This carriage is designed to replace the printed carriage and the acrylic glass plate at once. Which allows to lower the heatbed by 30 to 50 mm, gaining height for printing objects. WARNING: Not for printing but for cutting/milling (eg. acrylic glass)
WARNING: Not tested yet Other benefits
  • less tolerance in heatbed positioning
  • easier moving of the carriage than with 4x LM8UU (hopefuly)
    • Some dimensions:
  • Distance between Y-rods: 100 or 150 mm
  • Belt mount: M3, any size: 10 to 12.5 mm or 17.5 mm
  • Heatbed Mk2 mounted with 3x M3 screws, distance 209 mm
  • Holes are either 4.5 (KSTM) or 3 mm (others)
  • Total size: 229x229 mm (theoretically ;)
    • If you mount the the rods with 150 mm distance, you will:
  • be able to mount the motor inside the frame (not my invention). I added additional holes for the belt mount, so you can move the motor 11.5 mm from the center if it collides with the Y-rod mount.
  • gain fewer tolerance from warping of the Y-carriage
    • TO-DO
  • does it collide with anything?
  • how to mount the Y-end-stop?
  • will the motor collide with the plate if mounted inside the frame?
  • define screw length
  • draw Y-rod mounts for 150 mm distance
  • add a mount for a cable chain
    • Updates
  • Added holes for different size belt clamps: 10 to 12.5, 17.5 mm (did not update renderings)
  • Added nut holder for KSTM bearings

Requirements:
  • MendelMax 1.5, not sure about other versions.
  • Heatbed Mk2 or newer which has an additional hole to mount the heatbed with 3 screws
    • You will need to buy:
  • 3x Igus KSTM-08: http://www.igus.de/wpck/2486/igubal_Stehlager_KST?C=DE&L=en
  • 6x M4 screws, washers and nuts for mounting the KSTM-08
  • 4x M3 screws, washers and nuts for mounting the belt
  • 6x M3 screws, washers and nuts for mounting the heatbed
  • 3x M3 standoffs to raise the heatbed
    • Length of screws and standoffs depend on the thickness of your carriage plate and on the amount you want to raise the heatbed. You will need to print:
  • 2x belt clamps any size (10 to 12.5 mm or 17.5 mm)
  • maybe 3x clamps which hold the nuts for mounting the KSTM-08 (to be drawn)

title: Prusa I3 Rework Y-Motor mount with Solidworks 2014 source.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In a continual effort to make the rework better, more open, and/or more customized for my setup I redid the Y-Motor mount. I redid it in Solidworks 2014 and the source, for the original as well as my version, is included.
What I had to do for my bed was raise the heated bed, with the Boro glass on top and corrugated cardboard underneath, off of the Y plate or I could not level it. So, I replaced all hardware with Stainless since the plain metal m3 hardware was letting the heat flow easily to, what basically is, my Y plate heatsink. Once I did that I lifted the bed up, and off, the aluminum Y plate by about 5mm. What this allowed was the bed to be leveled pretty easily thanks to the Boro glass and with the machine printing the movements help air to flow underneath keeping it much much cooler (longer distance for the heat to travel and stainless conducts heat less easily). I also moved the slot in the mount forward by 2mm allowing my bed to have the full Y print area.

author: DarkAlchemist

description.text: When the filament spool has a core hole too small for the spindles on your printer this hooks on to the lip of the case and allows you to use spool with a small diameter hole. I ran into this when I bought some Taulman "Bridge" nylon filament. It is designed to hang on a slight angle to keep the spool on the spindle without requiring any kind of keeper on the end of the spindle. It will hang a Bridge spool above the spindle on the back of the machine without having to remove the machines built in spindle. Bridge comes on 1lb spools, the spindle should be able to support a 1 kg roll though may require removal of the built in spindle for clearance.

I used PLA but just about any type would do.
Set infill to 20%
Supports must be turned on to print properly.
Breaking the support structure off is not as easy as one might hope, particularly around the back side of the spindle. Unless it bugs you removal around the end of spindle is optional.

description.text:
Axe, pickaxe, hoe, sword, spade and egg - all in one handy Customizer thing!
Pick your weapon and scale (in tenths of a mm per 'cube').

I made this because my son, Sam, wanted to have little models of the Minecraft tools stuck to his bedroom wall.  
Rather than modelling by glueing each individual cube together separately I've done it row by row, using 'cubes' (actually cuboids) of height and depth 1, and length as long as required.  It could be done more efficiently by glueing together rows in places as you model but this was actually harder work for me because I used Excel inappropriately as a layout guide and auto-code-generator.  
I used the online tutorial to work out how to integrate with Customizer, which is ridiculously easy.  
I've loads more to add - this is just the start!

This is a spring suspension part that I made to be printed in one pass on a dimension sst 1200es.  My printed ABS suspension print is functional and I have made few modifications to the .stl which are included here. I wanted to make an air suspension, but the goal of this particular part was to design something that could be made in one single print.  The part was made in SolidWorks.
FYI - My printer uses support material as well as model material.  I'm not confident that this would print without the support material... yet.

• Print 2 suspensions for motorcycle or 4 for an ATV.
  • Tap both mounts with 7/8"
  • Mount to vehicle
  • Enjoy bottoming out the suspension! (It will hold like 5 pounds.)

title: Case for Transcend JetFlash JF150 USB flash drive

description.text: A case for the Transcend JetFlash JF150 USB flash drive, probably easily adaptable to other USB flash drives.

You can simply use the provided STLs. For a special effect, print the case with transparent material so the blue LED on the drive can shimmer through it. The case and lid are designed to hold the PCB and the USB plug by friction, you may need to remove some material after printing in order for the models to fit correctly, or apply some glue. The OpenSCAD sources needs obiscad and the provided USB icon. This thing is maintained on GitHub: https://github.com/rohieb/transcend-jetflash-jf150-case

title: Battery holders for AA and AAA types

description.text:
Those are battery holders with integrated wire connectors for AA and AAA batteries. It is partly a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9805 .
The electricity from a battery is conducted to wires through M3 countersunk screws and M3 embedded nuts. Wires are fixed between holder connectors and embedded nuts. A battery holder can be mounted using two M3 countersunk screws.
There are several holder models published both for AA and AAA batteries. Their filenames start with a battery type followed by an amount of batteries in a holder.

• Print it (AA_1_Battery_Holder.stl for a single AA battery, AAA_1_Battery_Holder.stl for a single AAA battery). If you are printing from ABS plastic and have a cooling fan (e.g. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32465 ) make sure that the fan is turned off. I have printed it using ABS plastic with 0.3mm layer height.
  • Clean the wire holes (which lead from bottom to nut holes) with a 2mm drill bit. You may use the following technique for cleaning holes: http://vimeo.com/14492980 (starting from 00:58 of the video).
  • Prepare 2 M3 nuts, 2 M3 countersunk screws, and 2 wires (per battery, see Details.jpg).
  • Put the M3 countersunk screws into battery connector holes (from battery side).
  • Insert stripped wires into 2mm connector holes and make sure that wires are visible in nut hole. It is shown on ConnectingWires.jpg.
  • Embed nuts and gently tighten screws to make a reliable connection, but do not over tighten them because the plastic part of a battery holder may crack.
  • Use another two M3 countersunk screws (not shown on Details.jpg) to attach the battery holder to a thing which needs it. For example, I have used it for boosting several toys which mistakenly believed that 1.5V alkalines are better to use than 1.2V NiMHs (UseCase.jpg). :-)

This is an OpenSCAD design of a ring to hold samples for light soaking in a solar simulator. Print and attach sample with binder clips and hold with chemistry clamp as in photo. For similar see the Open-Source Lab How to Build Your Own Hardware and Reduce Research Costs

description.text:
Just a simple block to go between serial connections. I use it between a DB-9 cable and a USB<> Serial adapter. We remove the thumbscrews and use a 1" machine screw to hold the parts together.
This block just fills in the space and makes it look better. Screws: 1" x 4-40 Phillips Pan Machine Screw from local hardware store. I printed it on a Replicator2 in low-res, 10% infill, 20mm layers.
Update: v3a adds a little taper to it, and readjusts the spacing of the screw holes slightly. Makes for a smoother fit. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/hiM1WoEcB6h

Made to fit between serial cable connections that don't use hex nuts to hold them together. Use some 1" machine screws to secure the cables and use this block to fill in the space. Helps to keep down the "wobble" between the connection and looks better.
Printed on a Replicator2 at 10% Infill, 20mm layers and 2 shells, using warm grey makerbot PLA. Matches my beige cable nicely.

focusing pair of reflecting lenses, rotary formation, caged, in line

Visit any brick-and-mortar business that has a service counter and you will likely see a small plastic or wood easel holding a stack of business cards.  I have also seen this type of easel used in restaurants, museums and offices holding up some kind of fixed message card.
The upper photo shows a business card (87mm X 50mm) on the easel to get an idea of size.  The easel itself is 47mm X 40mm (W X H) and leans back at something like 17 degrees.
This easel will hold a dozen flat business cards and there is a 0.7mm lip on the leading edge of the easel's ledge to help hold the cards in place.

This item was designed from the get-go to be 3D printed so it is easy to make compared to some of the objects I have submitted in the past.  You just print and use it.  When you load the easel with your business, information or description card, 99% of the object is hidden (so sanding is not needed).  The first test print, I broke the easel where it was attached to the raft so I thickened that surface (which holds up the finished easel).  Oh yeah, be careful when you are removing the raft anyhow.

Designed to fit a 2" Diameter round T-slot rail common in offices for dividers.   
The design uses a carrier and mount to sandwich a piece of material to serve as a shelf. 2x 3mx20mm pan head bolts and accompanying square nuts to secure.   
I used a 1/8" thick 12" x 8" piece of aluminum with beveled edges for the shelf itself. Each point of contact was roughed with coarse sand paper and affixed using epoxy.   
The shelf itself is quite secure but careful not to over load with heavy items.   
*added original shelf bracket, can be used for the top (shelf part 2) and/or bottom.

Printed with a Duplicator 4 in PLA -Use prt1B as the carrier (qty2)
-Use prt2 as the top or bottom bracket
-Use prt3 as the top or bottom bracket Use epoxy to affix the shelf to the brackets, rough each mating face with coarse sand paper. I found it easiest to apply epoxy while everything was mounted to the t-slot itself.

description.text: Along the lines of LeftAngle's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29214 but using a printed plastic part instead of glass to provide the offset. Sized for 3.3mm thick glass and Replicator 1. The goal is to trick your printer to make room for glass on the HBP.

Print (I used 20% fill, 0 extra shells). I got impatient and stopped it at 70%. It doesn't need to be as long as I made it.
Measure the thickness of the "top" (assuming you have oriented it as if you'll be clipping down onto something). I wanted this to be slightly less than my glass thickness (because I had a spring nearly slack), so I sanded it until this measured closer to 3.2mm. YBPMV. 
Note the location where the Z axis limit switch makes contact with the platform support structure when you do the "home axes" routine. Clip this onto the plywood at that location. Press firmly to ensure it's all the way on.
Your fingers may be more nimble than mine. I needed forceps to accomplish this.
Use caution as you go to home the axes for the first time with glass on there. Start, maybe, by cranking down on the adjustment nuts a half turn or so.

title: Tampstand for Rocket Espresso Portafilter (E61 brewhead)

description.text:
NOTE: Pictures of made item (Red ABS) are old version, please download v6 file for better single/dual spout compatibility!!)  
Espresso makes me happy.  Tamping a single spout portafilter without a tamp stand makes me sad.  Paying a ludicrous $80 or more for a stainless steel and marble-inlaid, buffed-with-virginal-baby-diaper-soft-cotton tampstand with some bozo logo on it makes me angry.  Me without espresso with a rich thick crema from the perfect grind and tamp, angry, makes the world a scary place.  I need to not be angry.  
Hence, the swooshy blended just-strong-enough it flexes a little to let me know when I'm tamping just right, ABS tampstand.  In red, because Rockets have red glare. :)  
5/11/2014: Updated with a v6 file with less faceting.  My original finally got overstressed and cracked, so rather than just reprint I did some redesign.  The new version fits both the single and dual spout portafilters and provides a bit more strength.  Since I needed an 'undercut' for the dual spout, the new file has integral support parts that are part of the print.  I prefer to design these in rather than let my slicer provide them since I can better control contact points and removability without excessively marring the desired finished part.

Should fit the portafilter for most Rocket Espresso machines (e.g. the Giotto, Cellini, R58, I think all use the same portafilter handle and basket sizes).  Update: The v5 file doesn't support the dual spout, although you can turn the stand around and just use it to hold up the handle end.  The new v6 file upload fits both single and dual spout portafilters.  It might also fit other brands that are based on the E61 brewhead, but I make no promises.  
If anyone wants the original design files to play around a bit more, please let me know; this was drawn in Creo Elements before the export to STL.  For example if you wanted a bit more radius blending where the horizontal tie bar connects to the arc section supporting the basket, to increase the strength a bit.  Then again, you can also vary the strength quite a bit with infill parameters.

comments.text: I honestly don't know.  I should post more pictures.  From the original picture of the first design, with the single portafilter in the old holder, you can see the spout is fairly 'central' under the middle of the espresso basket.  On my Rocket the double-spout holder has the spout assembled at the far end from the handle, so if you look at the picture of the new file, that's why I have the undercut at the non-handle end of the holder.

author: Taron

title: laser cut CNC linear axis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a design for a /really/ inexpensive linear axis mechanism for an open source selective laser sintering 3D printer that I've been designing (but it should be generally useable for anything that requires a one or two axis system). This is a follow up to the selective laser sintering alpha one dual Z tables that I recently posted ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3390 ). The innovations in this system are its extremely minimal vitamin count -- only a handful of bolts, washers, and nuts are required. It also uses several long pieces of kapton tape as a linear slide bushing, to dramatically reduce friction and drag (though regular old scotch tape may work just as well ;) ).

http://builders.reprap.org/2010/07/changing-game-and-using-kapton-tape-as.html ( the design was prototyped with 3mm material, but the material thickness isn't critical to the design ). The bolt holes should snugly fit 6-32 bolts. Update (from some questions recieved from folks who have made it: ) The width of the top plate (the one with 13 screw holes + 1 shaft hole, and the big curvy notch at the bottom) is 95mm wide by 102mm high, to help get your scale right. The steppers that Iâ€™m using are KP35FM2-035, which I get at Sayal Electronics ( http://www.sayal.com/ActionIndexP.asp?ID=162138 ), which has a bunch of stores in and around toronto, ontario, canada (and also an online presence, I think). These typically go for about $5, and I think they have a NEMA-14 footprint, with a 5mm shaft diameter. All the bolt holes are sized to snuggly fit 6-32 bolts, and you will likely have to tap these if you're using a material like acrylic (you can typically self-tap them with the bolt itself through a softer material like hardboard). The bolt holes are 3.4mm dia, while the gear hub holes are 4mm in diameter, making the gears loosely fit (and have a bit of play to find their place -- but you could certainly try cutting the gears with smaller holes to see if that works better). I used 3/4 inch length bolts, but some (for the gears) protrude out, so 1/2 inch would probably be more appropriate for these. I put a small washer on the underside (but not the top) of each gear to dramatically reduce the friction -- without the washers, the hardboard version doesn't work very well at all, but with them it works quite well. In addition, between each of the structural plates, I placed washers to give a little extra travel height for the gears. I have added two SVG files with the parts already layed out, that I used for laser cutting. There are some extra gears in there, just to fill out the space. I just put them in a ziplock bag full of gears for later tinkering, or give them away to friends who think they're the coolest thing ever :)

comments.text: That's definitely a design possibility, but that's similar to moving a table rather than having the (current) gantry design -- it would increase the footprint of the machine by double per axis, and for a 2 axis system it would increase the footprint by four times! description.text: This is a G-Code script for warming up your 3-D printer so you can print immediately when you want to print.  My Thing-O-Matic only can build things from the SD card and can jog... not control the heaters.

1) Open Warmup.gcode in RepG.
2) Adjust Temperatures if you need to.
3) Build to File on your SD card. (s3g file)
4) Run the Warmup.s3g on your Thing O Matic or other RepG controlled robot when you want to warmup the extruder and heated bed. I find it works fairly well. Just run it while you are waiting for Skeinforge to slice your print. :) That way when you actually get to printing it you don't have to wait for something else. I find you can take the SD card out while the program is running since this program is so short. This allows you to put your object to print on the SD card while the printer is warming up.

title: 10-20 to m8 nut adapter for thin threaded z rod

description.text:
This thing lets you use thinner z rod with your current m8 carriage ends. This is a test part that I printed but didn't end up testing. The theory is that a thinner z rod would be less likely to cause wobbles in the print if it was non-straight. This piece is the id of a 10-20 coupling nut (yes, I'm american... I know... It's what they have in stores here, so It's what I designed for...) and the od of an 8mm nut. You should be able to
1- print this,
2- press in a 10-20 coupling nut whilst still hot
3- swap out your flexible coupling for something that will grab the smaller 10-24 rod
4- use the same x-carriage and print with fewer wobbles!

For this to work you will need:
~26in of 10-20 rod.
4 10-20 coupling nuts. (these are longer than usual. Mine are 3/4" long)
your existing x axis, untouched.
your spring (if you use one) from between your m8 nuts.
something to couple your threaded rod to your motor shaft. There is an openscad and an stl, feel free to make a metric version if you live in the 21st century. Dependencies: MCAD NOTE: I designed this piece thinking that my z wobble was caused by my 8mm rods being bent. The real fix ended up being that my rods were constrained at the top and bottom. I used flexible tubing as a top coupler and got rid of the bottom bearing. I would recommend that fix first to anyone who is following down my same path. If that fails, try this part out and report back!

The base has been designed in 4 main components.
The main building houses living quarters command center and science wings for all project that are deemed non-hazardous to human habitation.
There is a separate building where science that may become dangerous is completed. This is where experimentation of biological organisms, generation methods for water and rocket fuel will occour.
There is a chemical processing plant, for routine processing of supplies would occur. These chemicals include oxygen extraction, water extraction and perchlorate extraction. As the hazardous science labs develop and test better methods this building would be expanded to integrate those techniques.
The final building is a food production facility where hydroponic and greenhouse techniques can be used to supply food for the colony. Robotic construction is achieved by combining regolith with imported polymers from Earth.
Basic construction is a layer of polymerized soil, a layer of "loose" soil (under vacuum), and finally an outer layer of more polymerized soil. The outer layer would also incorporate solar panels for power. After the material science and geological science teams develop a better construction medium it would be possible to build a new complex and recycle the original polymers for other uses.

The Mars station is bubble-like for many reasons. The half sphere shape is very aerodynamic and strong structurally, and with new inflatable materials can easily be transported, quickly constructed and withstand the harsh environmental conditions on Mars. The Mars bubble city would be large collectively and protect it’s inhabitants, but also could sections could easily be closed off due to emergency and people still could travel from sphere to sphere with ease. There are large access bays at each corner of the settlement for outside access if and when needed. There are mini spheres located at the top of each section for import instruments. The large sphere in the middle of the structure could provide the people with a total greenhouse, Earthlike area with plants, animals, and recreation land and water areas.

description.text: A fractal ornament for your Christmas tree. Merry Thingimas!

I really like the Koch snowflake - it is a very balanced shape that always strikes me as being quite festive. Here, I have punched the snowflake through the heart of a sphere and added a hanger to make a Christmas ornament.
It prints out very well on my Ultimaker with no fill. It needs a wall thickness of about 0.8mm to give it some mechanical strength, but still keep it quite light. It does not need any support, because the hanger on the top (on the side when you print) is inset into the body of the sphere sufficiently to make the slight overhang very manageable for most printers. Similarly, because of the truncated Snowflake faces, the overhang on the sphere is very small.
This is a derivative of Koch Snowflake Vase 1. If you want to play about with the SCAD file, you will need to also download Koch Snowflake Vase 1 to get my Koch Snowflake library.
Enjoy!

author: mgibson74

title: Telephone earring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wonder if anyone remembers the green phone with cord.
EVERYBODY had it back when our phone company still had the state monopol. Random thought:
I really should make a older version with a working phone dial.

Unfortunately the one in the picture was printed "phone side down", resulting in the spaker-holes not to show.
It's best printed on the side for higher detail (but cord will be less stable). You could print it standing up to avoid support material on the cord loops. Also, standing coils/springs tend to be a bit more stable due to layer orientation(see spring earring). PS: The model is not one shell, as usual, this was a daily-earring and therefore quick&dirty. It can cause some problems at the cord where the pieces join. You may want to check it (run it through meshlab/netfabb/etc.). Fun fact:
This one was done April-2011 and is one of the many earrings I have not uploaded for some reason.
I just discovered this due to the fact one of them broke and I went back to reprinting the model, checking Thingiverse for info on settings and orientation.
